instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.CHGR_CSI_P: What is CHGR_CSI_P? CHGR_CSI_P is one of the current sense lines for the charger. Resistance between CHGR_CSI_P and CHGR_CSI_N should be the resistance should be the total series resistance of the current sense resistors in the circuit, usually about 20.02 ohms.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.SMC_RESET: What is SMC_RESET? SMC_RESET is not a signal, it is an abbreviation for “SMC_RESET_L”, which is the signal someone is referring to when they type “SMC_RESET”  "SMC_RESET_L is a signal that resets the SMC when it is low(this is what the “_L” prefix means), and lets the SMC out of reset mode when it is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I have a board with no water damage or something close to that.
The board don't have green light, however, i get 3.42V and 17V
I check <RESISTOR>R5187</RESISTOR> (SMC ACOK) Pin 2, I get 3.42V and <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> as well.

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
Pin 1 = 0
Pin 5 = 0

<CAPACITOR>C7008</CAPACITOR> = 3.42V

<SIGNAL>CHGR_CSI_P</SIGNAL> Pin 28 = 3.9Ω short to ground (something is not right here)
I don't have <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

I feel a little lost. Can you guy help me out?

Thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
If you have a 3.9 ohm short to ground on pin 28 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> then you likely have a bad <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> or bad <CAPACITOR>C7121</CAPACITOR>. I would start by replacing this. I am surprised that you have <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> though if this is the case. 

1) Does <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> have 3.42v on pin 1?
2) Is <RESISTOR>R7029</RESISTOR> on the board?
3) Is <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> present? 

If all that is good I would start replacing <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: There is a short on PPDCIN somewhere. I doubt it will come from <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>. See if short is also present on <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR> and inject voltage there, see what heats up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
1) Does [URL="https://store.rossmanngroup.com/isl6259ahrtz.html"]<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>[/URL] have 3.42v on pin 1? Yes,
2) Is <RESISTOR>R7029</RESISTOR> on the board? Yes,
3) Is <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> present? Yes,

I replaced the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and i get my <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, however, my green light still off plus, my 5V is 4V.

Do you think i need replace again the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>?

Thank you for sharing your knowledge, Louis & Duke.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Exact voltage on PPBUS? ACOK present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: 12.36 means SMC is not running. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> high? If yes then probably dead SMC or crap under it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: So then crap under or SMC or dead SMC. Try running flux under it first. Make sure you remove edge bonding, but 12.36 is high enough for hope it's not dead lol.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I did, plus i put the board in the super sonic machine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Time to put another SMC on there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
SMC Replaced and everything looks normal, however, the audio doesn't work.
If i plug the Headphone nothing change as well.
Any hint from here?

Thank you guys

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Any audio device recognized? Can adjust volume in OSX?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Yes, i can.
When i plug the headphone, they system recognize as well, however, no sound

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Inspect <CHIP>U6201</CHIP> area and voltages to it. No chime also?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Not that much that could be wrong. I assume you did a PRAM reset and there still is no chime? It does look like a dead <CHIP>U6201</CHIP> then.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I will replace and let you know. 
Thank you
